title: K. J. V. Steenstrup
text:
Knud Johannes Vogelius Steenstrup (7 September 1842 – 6 May 1913) was a <a href="Danish%20people">Danish</a> <a href="geologist">geologist</a>. He was most noted as an <a href="exploration">explorer</a> of <a href="Greenland">Greenland</a>.
Biography.
Steenstrup was born at Høstemark Mill in Mou Sogn, <a href="Jutland">Jutland</a>, Denmark. He was the son of Johan Peter Steenstrup (1814–49) and Sinned Claudine Lund (1803–63),
He was a nephew of <a href="zoology">zoologist</a> <a href="Japetus%20Steenstrup">Japetus Steenstrup</a> (1813-1897).
Steenstrup took a degree in <a href="pharmacy">pharmacy</a> in 1863 and worked as assistant at the <a href="University%20of%20Copenhagen">University of Copenhagen</a> <a href="Geological%20Museum">Geological Museum</a> from 1866 to 1889. He made in total nine journeys to <a href="Greenland">Greenland</a>, one of which lasted 2.5 years. He made remarkable collections of Cretaceous and Paleogene plant fossils in central West Greenland, which were later treated by <a href="swiss%20people">swiss</a> <a href="botany">botanist</a> <a href="Oswald%20Heer">Oswald Heer</a> (1809–1883). Heer initially considered the fossils to be <a href="Miocene">Miocene</a> in age.
Steenstrup proved that the large <a href="iron">iron</a>-rich blocks found by <a href="Adolf%20Erik%20Nordenski%C3%B6ld">A.E. Nordenskiöld</a> on <a href="Disko%20Island">Disko</a>, and claimed by him to be <a href="meteorites">meteorites</a>, were in fact <a href="native%20iron">native iron</a> <a href="Extrusive">extrusions</a> in <a href="basalt">basalt</a>. This finding made his name well known and he was subsequently made honorary member of the <a href="Mineralogical%20Society%20of%20Great%20Britain%20and%20Ireland">Mineralogical Society of Great Britain and Ireland</a>. 
From 1889 to his death in 1913, he was state geologist at the <a href="Geological%20Survey%20of%20Denmark%20and%20Greenland">Geological Survey of Denmark</a>. Unfortunately, a large proportion of his <a href="Greenland">Greenland</a>ic collections were lost when <a href="Christiansborg%20Palace%23Second%20Christiansborg">Christiansborg Palace</a> burned in 1884. In his home country, he made pioneering studies of <a href="dune">dune</a> morphology.
Steenstrup was the first chairman of the Danish Geological Society from 1893 to 1898.
In 1895, he was made an honorary corresponding member of the <a href="Royal%20Geographical%20Society">Royal Geographical Society</a> in London, 
He was appointed <a href="Honorary%20degree">Honorary Doctor</a> at the <a href="University%20of%20Copenhagen">University of Copenhagen</a> in 1906. 
From 1896 he was a member of the <a href="Commission%20for%20Scientific%20Investigations%20in%20Greenland">Commission for Scientific Investigations in Greenland</a> and from 1902 fellow of the <a href="Royal%20Danish%20Academy%20of%20Sciences%20and%20Letters">Royal Danish Academy of Sciences and Letters</a>.
The twin <a href="K.J.V.%20Steenstrup%20Glacier">K.J.V. Steenstrup Glacier</a>s ("K.I.V. Steenstrups Nordre Bræ & K.I.V. Steenstrups Søndre Bræ") in <a href="King%20Christian%20IX%20Land">King Christian IX Land</a>, eastern Greenland, are named after him.
